sen.j: 総大将(そうだいしょう)とは、一軍以上編成する軍団において全軍を指揮する大将のこと。
sen.e: Sodaisho was a commander in chief who led the army composed of more than one corps.
Sodaisho was a commander in chief who lead an army composed of more than one corps.
Sodaisho was a commander in chief who lead an army composed of more than one corps.

sen.j: 特に一軍以上の軍団からなり複数の大将がいる場合に最高位にある者を差別化する場合、総大将ということが多い。
sen.e: Especially, the term Sodaisho was commonly used to mark off the highest-ranking official from the other generals in the army composed of more than one corps.
In particular, the term Sodaisho was often used to differentiate the highest ranking official from other generals in an army composed of more than one corps.
In particular, the term "Sodaisho" was often used to differentiate the highest ranking official from other generals in an army composed of more than one corps.
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを補足しました。

sen.j: 惣大将または主将、総帥ともいう。
sen.e: This was also called Sotaisho, Shusho, or Sosui.
Sodaisho were also referred to as Sotaisho, Shusho or Sosui.
Sodaisho were also referred to as Sotaisho, Shusho or Sosui.
What is Sodaisho
Summary
Summary

sen.j: 総大将とは、およそ日本の平安時代から戦国時代_(日本)にかけての合戦史上において全軍を率いた武将を指す場合に用いる概念である。
sen.e: Sodaisho was the concept used in referring to a military commander who led the whole army in the Japanese battle history from about the Heian to the Warring States periods.
Sodaisho is a concept used to refer to a busho (military commander) who lead an entire army within the battle history from the Heian to the Sengoku Period (period of warring states).
sen.cmt: changed "military commander" to "busho (military commander" as per the word list; Warring States period→Sengoku Period
sen.e: Sodaisho is a concept used to refer to a busho (military commander) who lead an entire army within the battle history from the Heian to the Sengoku Period (period of warring states).

sen.j: ひとつの武士団のみで軍勢を編成する場合、総大将は武門の棟梁が自ら務めるか、或いはその一門ないし家老など、身分の高い者の中から選抜されることも多く、陣中にあってその権限は大きかった。
sen.e: When troops were organized only by a single samurai group, a leader of the samurai clan himself served as Sodaisho, or Sodaisho was often selected from high-ranking warriors of the clan such as Karo (chief retainer); the powers of Sodaisho was great in the battle.

In a situation where troops were organzied by a single samurai group, the leader of the samurai clan served as Sodaisho, or in many other cases, a Sodaisho would be selected from high-ranking warriors of a clan such as the Karo (chief retainer) and they held great authority in battles.
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: In a situation where troops were organized by a single samurai group, the leader of the samurai clan served as Sodaisho, or in many other cases, a Sodaisho would be selected from high-ranking warriors of a clan such as the Karo (chief retainer) and they held great authority in battles.

sen.j: 複数の武士団により編成された連合軍の場合、指揮系統面においてそれぞれの武士団ごとに独立しており、総大将はあくまで盟主としての地位に過ぎず比較的権限が弱かった。
sen.e: When troops were organized by allied samurai groups, the chain of command was almost independent in each samurai group; Sodaisho was just a figurehead leader, and his power was relatively weak.

On the other hand, in the case of troops being organized by allied samurai groups, each group had an independent chain of command and the Sodaisho was just a figurehead with relatively weak authority.
sen.cmt: added "On the other hand" to contrast with the last sentence; fixed grammar
sen.e: On the other hand, in the case of troops being organized by allied samurai groups, each group had an independent chain of command and the Sodaisho was just a figurehead with relatively weak authority.

sen.j: しかし、いずれにしても全軍の頂点に立つ総大将の地位は武将にとり非常に魅力的であり、大名自身が総大将を務めない場合、一門や家臣の間でその地位を競うこともあった。
sen.e: In either case, the position of Sodaisho, who stood at the top of the whole army, was very attractive for military commanders; when the position of Sodaisho was not performed by Daimyo (feudal lords), his family and retainers competed for the position.

In either case, however, the position of Sodaisho standing at the top of the entire army was extremely appealing, so when the post was not performed by the Daimyo (Japanese territorial lord), the lord's family members and retainers competed for the position.

In either case, however, the position of Sodaisho standing at the top of the entire army was extremely appealing, so when the post was not performed by the Daimyo (Japanese territorial lord), the lord's family members and retainers competed for the position.

sen.j: 戦国時代になると戦国大名は自家の軍制において侍大将、足軽大将などの職制及び階層を定めたため、それらを率いる武将の地位を総大将と称した。
sen.e: In the Warring States period, the Warring lords established the role and the class in their military organizations such as Samurai daisho (commander of warriors) or Ashigaru taisho (general in command of a troop of foot soldiers); the position of a military commander who led those people was called Sodaisho.

As it become the Sengoku Period, when daimyo established the commanding positions and classes in their military organizations such as the Samurai daisho (commander of warriors) or Ashigaru taisho (general in command of a troop of food soldiers), the military commander in charge of these positions was referred to as a Sodaisho.
sen.cmt: Warring States period→Sengoku Period; Warring Lords→daimyo; fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: As it become the Sengoku Period, when daimyo established the commanding positions and classes in their military organizations such as the Samurai daisho (commander of warriors) or Ashigaru taisho (general in command of a troop of food soldiers), the military commander in charge of these positions was referred to as a Sodaisho.
